awd_titl_txt: IRES: Closing Oceans: Assessing the Dynamics of Turkish suture zones
awd_abstract_narration:
IRES: Closing Oceans: Assessing the Dynamics of Turkish suture zones
PI: Catlos, co-PI: Elliott, Kyle

PART 1:
This International Research Experiences for Students (IRES) program provides four weeks of geological field-based research and training experiences across Turkey for 12 US students. Over the next 3 years, these students will investigate suture zones,i.e.locations where ancient ocean basins closed across the country. Turkey contains a large number of these zones, which are key locations used by geologists to understand how continents grow. Continental growth is considered one of the most important problems facing Earth Scientists, yet models for the process are debated, due in part to a lack of geologic record. Because of its extensive outcrops of ancient rocks associated with suture zones, Turkey is an ideal location to study this process.

The IRES program has societal value, as Turkey's suture zones can be associated with important ore and mineral resources or are regions of major, present-day geologic hazards. Older faults that worked to close the ocean basins today form regions of active earthquake activity or have generated topography that leads to large landslides. Understanding the locations and ages of Turkey's ancient suture zones has an impact on diverse topics, including mineral exploration and hazard reduction. This proposal includes partnerships with faculty at three Turkish universities (Dokuz Eylul University, Middle East Technical University, and Karadeniz Technical University) who will serve as mentors. Students chosen to participate are underrepresented in the geosciences and are selected via Jackson School and UT Austin outreach programs. Students will partner with Turkish researchers to explore a range of geological concepts discussed in their courses while making a significant impact on our understanding of processes related to the formation of continental crust. Students will apply innovative methods to address scientific questions involving both the timing and impacts of Turkey's suture zones, including electronic-based field mapping techniques and new geochemical approaches. This in turn will lead to insight into how the past geological history of Turkey impacts its present day concerns, including the development of economically important resources and hazard mitigation.  


PART 2:
Understanding how continents grow is recognized as one of the most important geodynamic problems facing Earth Scientists. Models for the process are debated, due in part to a lack of exposure of the geologic record. Because of its extensive exposures of ancient ocean suture zones and crustal fragments, Turkey is an ideal location to study this process. This International Research Experiences for Students (IRES) program provides four weeks of geological field-based research and training experiences across Turkey for 12 US students. Over the next 3 years, these students will investigate the arc accretion processes that occurred in Turkey during the closure of branches of ancient ocean basins.

In addition, the IRES program has societal value, as paleogeographic reconstructions are used to identify important economic resources that formed during specific times in Earth's history and assess geologic hazards that result due to reactivation of older faults or mass movement of rocks. This proposal includes partnerships with faculty at 3 Turkish universities (Dokuz Eylul University, Middle East Technical University, and Karadeniz Technical University) who will serve as mentors. Students chosen to participate are underrepresented in the geosciences and are selected via Jackson School and UT Austin outreach programs. Students will partner with Turkish researchers to explore a multidisciplinary range of geological concepts discussed in their courses while making a significant impact on our understanding of processes related to the formation of continental crust. Students will apply new and innovative field mapping, geochemical, and geochronological methods, lending greater insight into the history and mechanics of the assembly of Turkey.

INTRODUCTION: This NSF-IRES opportunity provided three weeks of geological field-based research and training experiences across Slovakia for US students (nine undergraduates and two graduate students). Students conducted research within a multidisciplinary, regional framework focusing on investigating geological processes that occur during the closure of branches of ancient ocean basins. Due to political issues, we changed the award venue from Turkey to Slovakia. Due to COVID, we canceled the last international field season. However, this cohort of students worked in UT Austin facilities on previously collected samples from field areas in Turkey and Slovakia. Our primary international partners were from Comenius University in Bratislava and the Earth Science Institute in the Slovak Academy of Sciences.

The primary goals for the NSF-IRES program were:

Fall Semester: Recruit. Despite issues facing political turmoil in Turkey and problems associated with the COVID pandemic, the recruiting plan was successful. We recruited students outside UT Austin's Jackson School of Geosciences (JSG), including from UT Austin's Cockrell School of Engineering and Austin Community College. Most students were selected from the JSG.

Spring Semester: Prepare. Students learned about the field area and conducted preliminary research. In 2016 and 2018, students enrolled in a course designed for the IRES. The course had specific goals, including meeting with UT Austin's International Office (Texas Global), faculty and staff from relevant international departments and centers, and JSG Walter Geology Librarian and Writer-in-Residence. 

Summer Session: Go. Students conducted fieldwork with IRES PIs, international colleagues, and Slovak students. Students learned from Slovak researchers and professors who openly embraced the opportunity to collaborate and educate. We visited historical and active underground mines, active fault sites, and regions where environmental remediation occurred. We hiked portions of the Western and High Tatra Mountains and sampled rare-metal granites of central Slovakia. Visits were made to Comenius University in Bratislava and the Slovak Academy of Sciences. Because we did not travel internationally in 2021, IRES students conducted geochemical research on previously collected rocks.

Fall Semester: Propose, Present, and Share. Each student conducted and presented their research projects to the broader scientific community. Most students submitted proposals to fund their research and conference attendance. Proposals were funded by UT Austin's Center for Russian, East European, and Eurasian Studies (CREEES), Texas Global, UT Austin's undergraduate research fellowship program, and Geological Society of America (GSA) South Central Section.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The Carpathians are considered a "type location" for a curved orogenic belt. The Western Carpathian Mountains, in particular, have been a focus of fundamental models for the development of the lithosphere that advanced our understanding of the crustal response to collision. Although the evolution of these mountains has been stated to be "critical" to understanding the Cenozoic development of the central parts of the Western Carpathians, little consensus exists regarding underlying controls on its development. IRES students worked on understanding the tectonic history of the Western and High Tatra Mountains. The results outline the earliest tectonic history until the onset of more recent exhumation and impact our understanding of the origin and development of the arcuate mountain belt.

Small exposures of rare-metal granites occur in central Slovakia as part of the Gemeric Superunit. Their ages impact understanding how this portion of the Carpathians relates to similar-age granites throughout Europe and the Western Mediterranean. IRES students presented new ages and geochemical data from several Gemeric granite exposures. Their data link the Western Carpathians to a regional widespread occurrence of Permian magmatism in the European and Western Mediterranean realms, consistent with regional magmatic re-equilibration of the Moho at this time.

IRES students also worked on specific ore deposits in Slovakia. Their work impacts our understanding of how specific economically significant deposits (in particular gold and magnesite-Co-Cu) originate as a fundamental part of the geologic evolution of a region.

BROADER IMPACTS: The IRES program improved the performance, skills, or attitudes of members of underrepresented groups that will improve their access to or retention in research, teaching, or other related professions. This is demonstrated by the employment of former IRES students in STEM fields and the retention of current students in geosciences programs at UT Austin and UT El Paso. IRES students indicated that the program was genuinely transformative in their career directions and goals. All IRES students learned more about how geoscience research is conducted with rocks they collected themselves. They developed skills from basic (sample preparation) to advanced (using high-level scientific instruments). They built international connections and gained experience presenting research results at conferences. They were trained to write competitive proposals. The PIs significantly expanded the field training of IRES students. The curriculum in the JSG provides little exposure to economic geology. This portion of the IRES experience cannot be replicated in the classroom and allowed students to interact with topics that are not covered in detail in their curriculum.
